Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Models for Mapping Genetic and Environmental Effects Regulating Shape Variation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolution and natural selection have produced an extraordinary diversity in shape and form among microbes, plants, insects, animals, and humans. This project develops new statistical methods for understanding how genetics and environmental factors combine to influence plant and animal morphology. Leaf morphology is a key plant phenomenon that is sensitive to environmental stimulus and is important for plant growth. Studying leaf shape leads to a better understanding of ecology, evolution and atmosphere-biosphere interactions and implications (e.g., climate change). This project focuses on the species Arabidopsis thaliana, a small flowering Eurasian plant that is commonly used in plant genetics studies because of the nature of its genome and the availability of its genetic data. This project promotes interdisciplinary cooperation and training between investigators and students in statistics, image analysis, genetics, biology, and computer science. The tools produced by this project are applicable for broader data-intensive and analytic research in paleoclimatology, anthropology, agriculture, developmental biology, evolution, ecology, and biomedicine.

In this project, the Arabidpsis thaliana plant is cultivated under controlled conditions in a growth chamber, and photographs document the shapes of mature leaves. Then high-dimensional curves are used to create an accurate representation of individual leaf shape. With each shape uniquely described, a two-stage statistical model, integrating Bayesian Lasso and Functional Data Analysis, is utilized to detect significant genes that regulate shape. A subset of genetic markers, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), which significantly effect shape and respond to environmental factors, is selected. Then the high-dimensional curve modeling is used to gain knowledge of the detailed genetic and biological functions of the candidate SNP markers. Combining high-dimensional data analysis that assesses leaf shape with the examination of thousands of SNP markers requires computationally intensive methods, both with respect to algorithms and data management. The tools developed will be made available in user-friendly R and Matlab packages designed for high-performance computing environments, for broad use by researchers with similar interests in shape analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research developed a series of innovative statistical methodologies to improve the existing approaches in the quantitative genetic shape mapping field and provided analytical guidance for biological questions. The proposed approaches input shape images together with genetic and/or environmental explanatory variables and output the relative importance rank of each variable in terms of its association strength with shape variation. We overcome the high dimensionality challenges from two aspects, selecting important explanatory variables from an extremely large scale of candidate pool and modeling the shape trait by a high dimensional curve or vector.

 

We compared the new methods with traditional statistic approaches existing in current quantitative shape mapping literature, say multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and linear mixed models (LMM), and demonstrated the outperformance of our approaches in accuracy. When applying our approach to a poplar leaf shape, we also empirically verified that gene*environment interactions indeed have crucial effects on the variation of leaf shapes and analytically confirmed some findings got by other studies of climate-leaf associations. Specifically, we found that the global shape variation (changes from ovate-lanceolate, to ovate, to cordate, including length to width ratio changes) is mainly controlled by genetic effects, and the local subtle variations (teeth-level changes) are modified by environmental factors. We reported that latitude is strongly associated with the subtle variation near the leaf tip and petiolar sinuses. The leaf petiolar sinuses from the south were more likely to be convex, compared with those from the north.

 

This research is multidisciplinary closely involving genetics, statistics, image, and biology. Modeling the interactive genetic and environmental mechanisms for shape or other biological traits has broader impacts for a spectrum of scientific disciplines including paleoclimate, anthropology, agriculture, developmental biology, evolution, ecology, and biomedicine, and so on. Moreover, we incorporated our research results into course development, mentoring of graduate students, and dissemination of our results through publications in top quality journals.
